articles.headline: A Chinese Tycoon Sought Power and Influence. Washington Responded.
articles.snippet: Ye Jianming courted the Biden family and networked with former United States security officials. Today, his empire is crashing down in court.
articles.abstract: Ye Jianming courted the Biden family and networked with former United States security officials. Today, his empire is crashing down in court.
articles.lead_paragraph: He struck billions of dollars’ worth of deals in Russia, Eastern Europe and Africa. He sought business with war-torn places like Chad and with international pariahs like North Korea.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson, David Barboza, Matthew Goldstein and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: While Working for Trump, Giuliani Courts Business Abroad
articles.snippet: Ethics experts say Rudolph W. Giuliani risks blurring lines by seeking contracts with foreign governments even as he remains President Trump’s personal lawyer.
articles.abstract: Ethics experts say Rudolph W. Giuliani risks blurring lines by seeking contracts with foreign governments even as he remains President Trump’s personal lawyer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel’s investigation was grinding relentlessly onward, with President Trump’s former national security adviser pleading for leniency in his case and his former fixer about to be sentenced for his crimes. But Mr. Trump’s personal lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, was in Manama, Bahrain, on Tuesday, meeting with the king and the interior minister of an important United States ally in the Middle East.

articles.headline: Theresa May Survives Leadership Challenge, but Brexit Plan Is Still in Peril
articles.snippet: A party vote left her in power, but her government’s plans on how to leave the European Union were left in disarray.
articles.abstract: A party vote left her in power, but her government’s plans on how to leave the European Union were left in disarray.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s prime minister, Theresa May, survived the gravest threat yet to her embattled leadership on Wednesday, winning a party confidence vote and averting a leadership battle that threatened to plunge the country into prolonged crisis.

articles.headline: A Weakened China Tries a Different Approach With the U.S.: Treading Lightly
articles.snippet: Hobbled by a slowing economy, the Chinese government has opted for a measured response to the arrest of a Huawei executive.
articles.abstract: Hobbled by a slowing economy, the Chinese government has opted for a measured response to the arrest of a Huawei executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The recent arrest of a top Chinese tech executive at the Trump administration’s request seemed certain to provoke a geopolitical showdown pitting Beijing against Washington.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher, Alan Rappeport and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Troubled by Lapses, Government’s Voice to the World Braces for New Trump Management
articles.snippet: The agency that oversees Voice of America and other government broadcasting has endured a series of recent scandals. Soon, a Trump appointee will take over.
articles.abstract: The agency that oversees Voice of America and other government broadcasting has endured a series of recent scandals. Soon, a Trump appointee will take over.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American government’s broadcast service to the world has a problem: It is becoming the news itself.

articles.headline: Nissan and Renault Face Leadership Crisis After C.E.O. Is Jailed
articles.snippet: Carlos Ghosn’s arrest leaves the Franco-Japanese car alliance that revolved around him in limbo. There is no clear plan to fill the power vacuum.
articles.abstract: Carlos Ghosn’s arrest leaves the Franco-Japanese car alliance that revolved around him in limbo. There is no clear plan to fill the power vacuum.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the nearly two decades he dominated the alliance of Renault and Nissan, Carlos Ghosn achieved something of a miracle in the auto world. He managed to get the French and Japanese companies to act as one entity so both could prosper in an industry where scale is everything.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Motoko Rich and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Mattel’s Revival Plan: Bet on Barbie, the Movie
articles.snippet: Ynon Kreiz, the toy giant’s fourth leader in five years, has a strategy for reversing its fortunes. And it starts with putting one of America’s best-known dolls on the big screen.
articles.abstract: Ynon Kreiz, the toy giant’s fourth leader in five years, has a strategy for reversing its fortunes. And it starts with putting one of America’s best-known dolls on the big screen.

articles.headline: In France, School Lessons Ask: Which Twitter Post Should You Trust?
articles.snippet: To combat online misinformation and radicalization, one of the world’s largest national internet literacy efforts is teaching students how to spot junk information.
articles.abstract: To combat online misinformation and radicalization, one of the world’s largest national internet literacy efforts is teaching students how to spot junk information.
articles.lead_paragraph: VAULX-EN-VELIN, France — A group of teenagers recently swarmed into a room at Collège Henri Barbusse near Lyon, France, for a class typically dedicated to learning Spanish. But on that Wednesday, an unusual lesson awaited them.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Elian Peltier

articles.headline: Europe’s Central Bank Ends One of the Biggest Money-Printing Programs Ever
articles.snippet: The end of the so-called quantitative easing effort is a milestone for the euro and a signal that the European Central Bank is confident enough in the eurozone’s health.
articles.abstract: The end of the so-called quantitative easing effort is a milestone for the euro and a signal that the European Central Bank is confident enough in the eurozone’s health.
articles.lead_paragraph: Frankfurt — One of the biggest money-printing programs of all time, a geyser of cash that may have prevented the collapse of the eurozone, will officially end in a few weeks in a slow-motion wrap-up that reflects lingering risks to the region.
